segments.text: Deep in his heart, every man longs for a battle to fight, an adventure to live, and a beauty to rescue.
This is one of my favorite quotes about masculinity, and if you've been following us for very long,
you've heard it from me a thousand times. Today, I'm honored and have the privilege of talking
with the author of that quote, and one of my top five recommended books on masculinity wild at
heart. His name is John Eldridge. We talk about the secret to a man's soul. The single greatest
question every man needs to have answered, society's attack on gender, how to embrace authentic
masculinity and why every man is wild at heart. You're a man of action. You live life to the
fullest, embrace your fears, and boldly charge your own path. When life knocks you down, you get
back up one more time, every time. You are not easily deterred or defeated, rugged, resilient,
strong. This is your life. This is who you are. This is who you will become. At the end of the day,
and after all is said and done, you can call yourself a man.
Men, what is going on today? My name is Ryan Micler, and I am the host of this podcast,
The Order of Man. I am stoked to be joining with you today, as I always am, but particularly today,
since I have one of my favorite authors on the show, and a man who has an incredible,
an incredible handle on what we as men are experiencing in life. If you are new to the show today,
you picked a great one to join us on. We are interviewing the world's most successful men.
We're extracting their lessons, their insights, their ideas. We're delivering them straight to you.
We've had some incredible guests. I think most of you can agree on the show. If you haven't gone
back and listened to shows like Jocko Willink, Tim Kennedy, Andy Fresilah, Brett McKay, so many
more, I'd encourage you to go back and tune into those shows. And if you would, please also make
sure to leave us a rating and review as I read every single one of those, and of course,
appreciate it when you do. Now, I'm not going to bombard you with announcements today.
We always have a lot going on. Sometimes it seems like too much, but right now I've got my head
down on a couple of different things. Number one is our live meetup in Nashville, January 26th
and 27th. And it's also going to be a book launch party for the book that comes out in February.
So make sure if you would, go check that out and join us register at orderofman.com
slash Nashville. That's orderofman.com slash Nashville. Now I want to introduce you to my
guest. Again, I'm honored to have him on the show. His name is John Eldridge. When I set out on this
journey to become a better man, his book, Wild at Heart, was one of my go-to resources for an
understanding of who I am as a man and how men show up in this world. Now, at the time, I never
thought that I actually had the chance to have a conversation with him, but after some back and
forth and getting our schedules pinned down, we were finally able to lock something in. John is
an author, a counselor, a teacher. He's been working with men and teaching them how to transform their
lives for more than two decades. It's really interesting to see that the book Wild at Heart
still strikes a nerve with me and thousands and thousands of men across the world more than 15
years after he wrote it. This is a testament to John's understanding of what we as men are
really after in our lives and how to become the men that we are meant to be.
John, welcome to the show. So glad to have you on today. Yeah, thanks, Ryan. Really glad to be
with you. Wild at Heart, which is the discussion that we're going to have today, is one of my
favorite books on the topic of masculinity and one that I recommend to all the guys that I talk with.
I'm thinking about this. It's actually been over 15 years since you wrote this book, but
I think it continues to be something that is very impactful in men's lives. What do you attribute
the duration of popularity of this book to? Well, I think because it hit on some really
universal themes, one of the cool stories of Wild at Heart is not just that it's kind of
carried on over the years, but it's in a bunch of foreign languages in countries that you would
think, oh, that's not going to work. Culturally, it's in Slovakia. It's the best-selling book
for men in Slovak. It's in Colombia. It's being used down in the Amazon. I mean, just
places that you just go, okay, hang on a second. Something in Wild at Heart touched a chord
that seems pretty universal to guys. What do you think that is? I think first off,
giving guys permission to be men. I think there's a lot of books out there that have advice,
and there's a lot of books out there with here is what you ought to be, but pressure doesn't
exactly inspire. There's something in the realm of permission to get in touch with your own passions,
get in touch with your core being as a man, and feel free to live from that. I think that's what
it's one of the deep things guys are really connecting with.
Why do you think it's been so difficult? Because I hear some people will say things like there's
an attack on masculinity, and others will say, well, it's just the nature of modern times.
What do you think that is attributed to? Oh, no, no. We are in a time of massive gender collapse.
It's not just an attack on masculinity because it's also an attack on femininity. I mean,
I was looking at a cover story of a magazine earlier this year on gender, and that picture
was about eight young people, young millennials in their 20s, and the spectrum was you might be
male, you might be female, you might be transgendered, you might be lesbian, you might be gay,
you might be queer, and the message that the world has embraced right now is that gender
is a spectrum. It's not a fixed thing. It's fluid, it's movable, and you can kind of choose
what you want your gender expression to be. So even the idea of masculinity now is something that
it's not so much a tact, it's just completely dismissed.
Why do you think that's the way that it is? We can talk a lot about whether it's governments,
or the media, or big business. There's a lot of things that are play here, but why do you think,
in general, there is this notion and gravitation towards gender fluidity?
Well, these are really good questions, by the way, because we're diving straight into some
of the deepest things in life. We don't mess around here, we get right into it.
No, you don't. Okay, so you have to understand that on two levels. First off, human brokenness
is more profound right now than it may have ever been on the earth. You just take incidences,
for example, of sexual abuse, sexual trauma early in life has increased over the past century,
and that does serious damage to your view of your gender, who you are, either as a man or
as a woman. So you have to understand the effect of trauma on a widespread cultural basis, both
for men and women, particularly sexual trauma. But you also have to understand if you believe in any
kind of battle, there is a massive war against humanity. I mean, there is real evil, and evil
hates humanity, and it is attacking us in the core of our being, which I think gender is absolutely
core to the human race. Like everything you do, you do as a man, or you do as a woman. Like,
masculinity is so core to how men are created that when evil attacks us there, it brings in a
level of confusion and doubt. And then you just add the sociological layer, you just add the crisis
of fatherlessness. Gender identity is bestowed by the father. Boys look to their death, or to the
key man in their life to learn who they are as men. They can't get it from their moms, they can't
get it from other boys, they sure can't get it from girls, although they try. And so you also
just have that sociological layer of the crisis of fatherhood. So many men growing up without a real
dad in their life, you put those things together and it's a training wreck.
Yeah, it's really interesting. One of the chapters in the book, you actually talk about this with
the rise of boys being raised without fathers. And that was me. I was raised primarily by my
mother and my sister was in the picture. And it was really fascinating going through this
chapter in the book and and realize in a way that I wanted to be free from her little boy, if you will.
And that chapter resonated with me so much, so much so that I remember getting on the phone with
my mom not long after I originally read the book and I've read it multiple times now.
And she would call me honey and sweetie and sweetheart. And for the first time I realized like,
that's not who I want to be. That's not who I identify as a man. And so I remember having the
conversation of please don't use those words anymore, because I do want to be free. I do want to be
masculine and you're keeping me here as a little boy, it seemed like. Wow, that's huge. That's just
huge. Yeah, really interesting perspective. You know, you also talk about with this attack, you
know, I look at pornography, for example, and then also just the breakdown of the family unit and
society's attack on the family. Do you see those as being key perpetrators, I guess, on this attack
as well? Well, okay, so here this is going to help guys understand the pornography thing,
because the core issues of pornography have nothing to do with sex. The experience of coming alive
as a man is so rare in our culture right now, that when a guy experiences pornography, I mean,
it fires things inside of us. Yeah, sure. Right. And there's an a sense of a live
that he does not experience anywhere else in his life, not his work, not in his friendships,
not not maybe a church if he's into that, not at home. And so the core issue is the more that a man
is wholehearted as a man, the more that he knows who he is, and he has a deep settled experience of
being alive as a man, pornography begins to look like cotton candy. Like it's just it doesn't work.
It's not what I'm looking for. It's it's a false high. It's like meth. How does a man then begin to
know who he is? Well, you got to start in a couple places. And actually, like you asked,
why did you think, well, the parts continue to do so well as a book? I think because the very first
thing it does for guys, the subtitle is discovering the secret of a man's soul.
That the first thing to say to guys is you have an interior world and your inner world
is more important than your external world. And most of the stuff online, if you look up, you know,
how to be a real man or, you know, seven tips for growing as a man, most of its external stuff,
you know, it's learned to work on your car or learn to handle money, that kind of thing.
Good things, sure, but wild at heart and books like it that are popular to do well,
help men with their inner world. So when you ask, what does it mean to find out who you really are
as a man, we got to start with the interior life. And we got to back up to little boys and you got
to say every little boy is basically asking one question. He's asking, do I have what it takes?
The search for validation fuels a man's behavior just about every day of his life. Like right now,
in this podcast, I'm very aware of as a man, I want to do very well that the search for validation
is huge. Now as a little boy, do I have what it takes? And whether he gets a good answer to that
question is just huge. So how do I kind of know who I am as a man, come alive as a man? Who answered
your question? Now for you, it was your mom and it was sweetie and sweetheart and honey.
And while those are very endearing, by the way, that's precious stuff. It doesn't answer the
question. It tells the boy he's sweet. It tells the boy he's tender, but it does not tell the boy
that he has what it takes. Right? Sure. Okay. So for guys listening to this and they're going,
oh man, how did you get your question answered? Did your dad answer it? And a lot of guys didn't
have a dad there to answer it or if their dad was there, they got a horrible answer. They got,
my dad, my dad used to call me worthless. Now it was partly playful. He was also kind of a dick
sometimes, but the thing is you tell a boy that enough over the course of his life, hey, worthless
is what he would say to me when I walk in the room. That begins to answer the question, do I have
what it takes? No, you don't have what it takes. And so this core question, M-I-A-M-A-N,
you got to start with who has named you, who got to answer that question so that they can do,
like you do with your mom, you got to say, you know what, I actually reject that answer. I'm not
just sweet. I'm not just a good boy. I'm not soft. You can begin to reject that answer and you begin
to search for a real one. It's really fascinating that you talk about this because I have made a
commitment to coach my boys baseball, football, and basketball teams and we just got into basketball.
And it's really interesting to watch my two oldest boys who, my six-year-old, they don't keep score
at this age. At nine, they do it six, they don't. And it was really funny, we just had our last
basketball game. After the game was over, the six-year-old boys immediately. First question after the
game was over, coach, who won? Which I think, to your point, is a version of asking,
do I have what it takes? Did I beat the other team? Did I do what I needed to do?
Totally. Exactly. Right. And so in a culture where everybody gets a trophy,
not helpful, not helpful because it doesn't bring the affirmation he's looking for.
Who won? Did we kill him? Did we do it? Like, M-I-powerful is another way of saying the same question.
M-I-powerful. A man wants his words to be powerful. He wants his actions to be powerful. He wants his
decisions to matter. You get into it like a corporate job, man. And you don't get to make
decisions. And your words, you got to be really careful with your words. The world emasculates men.
And so in a ballgame like that, you're looking for someplace to know, did we do it? Did we kill
them? Right. And be powerful. Did we win? Right?
Let's look at the other side of this because I know that there's going to be people saying this,
and I can even hear this, is that looking to some sort of external metric or validation of a man's
worthiness is an unhealthy practice. What are your thoughts there? Yes and no. Okay, so,
yeah, how much money you make doesn't matter. Right, right. How beautiful your date is, doesn't
matter. Some of those things are false and the world is full of it. I was just watching a,
watching the World Series and some of the commercials on there. I mean, they know who's watching,
right? So most of the commercials are designed for men. Matthew McConaughey is driving this new,
I think it's a Lincoln. And he's dressed to the tee. He's got the ladies and everything else.
Exactly, exactly. And the message is, if you get that, you're a man. So that stuff's not helpful.
That is the world's version of it. But yes, of course there are external metrics in the sense of,
does your life matter? Are you making a difference? What is your impact on the world? You know, again,
World Series commercials, the new Call of Duty video game commercial, it is brilliant. It is so
brilliant because it just appeals to the core of men and it's a World War II type battle video
game. And the idea being, you know, it's talking about brotherhood and courage and valor.
Right. Okay, that stuff is huge. They are tapping into the spine of men. Like, yeah,
you want your life to matter. Do I live with courage? Do I live with valor? Do I have brotherhood in
my life? Some of those external things are important to ask. Yeah, this makes total sense. And I think
part of the reason why this book has done so well, and of course, even your continued work and my
work as well, because I think to some degree, we recognize this, I want to go back because you
talked about going to the internal versus external. I think most men probably look to external sources,
external validation, get the car, get the money, get the girl, get the vacations, get the house,
get the thing, right? Is it that it's just more time consuming or harder or they don't know how
to turn inside versus outside? Why is it such a challenge for men to turn inwards?
Well, there's a couple things. One is fear. Fear is big. And the other is he probably doesn't
have a guide. Men were meant to be fathered. We were meant to be initiated, you know, the ideal
experience. And you look back through this is just so true over culture and over history, you know,
whether you look at the Vikings or the Irianjaya in New Guinea, or you just take any, any people
group, they had a means of initiating boys. And it was older men showing the younger men and the
boys how to do it. And so especially when you're talking about your inner world, okay, so fear
and the lack of a guy, because the core issue is this, every man has a wounded heart. And the wounds
that he's taken are primarily in the place of validation. No, you don't have what it takes, you
know, and I could, you know, the stories that I have from counseling guys are pretty horrific,
but the violence, the sexual assault, the abandonment, the heinous things done and said to boys in their
journey to become men, every man has got a wound in his soul. Every man does, you don't get through
this war without it. And to go back into that wound and say, and it's almost always a father
wound, by the way, because again, the father was meant to bestow the masculine identity, to go back
into that wound feels like a scary thing. It feels like, man, I just feel weak when I'm there. I don't
know what to do with it. It's a risk, right? It's a big risk. And that's why I write, that's why you
do your podcast, like we're trying to offer a guide, we're trying to help guys say, no, no,
no, you can do this, you can do this. The fight for your heart is your biggest fight. And as you
begin to get more and more of your heart back, you are going to be an unstoppable force. So it is
totally worth the risk. If you've never had any sort of rite of passage, and I'll just go back
to my childhood, I didn't have this, my dad wasn't around to tell me you're a man now.
But I got a lot of that through my time playing sports in high school. My mom was fortunately
had enough insight and knowledge and ideas to put me in sports with other men and boys. I joined
the military when I was 18 years old and got a lot of it there. But how does a man who never received
some sort of passage receive this or create this for himself? Yeah, I think you just gave a couple
big examples. It's available. It's available, guys. It's available. But you do have to be intentional.
And some of it comes through the company of other men. And so get yourself in the company
of good men. If it's guys going out bird hunting, or if it's guys who are fixing cars in a shop,
or if it's guys who love to do a hike every weekend, and they love to just go into the mountains or
whatever, it could be down at the why, shooting hoops, get yourself in the context where that
can take place. But the issue we're kind of skirting around here a little bit is,
and I thought Dennis Prager was fascinating on this. He's a Jewish scholar, really brilliant guy.
And he was trying to explain the Old Testament. And he said, the reason that God is presented as
father has almost entirely to do with the fact that young men need initiation. And so he was
really dialed into the sociological realities of the need for initiation and the failure of modern
era to offer it. And his whole point, I think is very, very true, is that there is a father,
there is a father who can speak into your life, and who can provide initiation experiences
if you will let him. And so you got to, we're obviously into faith questions and issues like
that. But that's a big, big offer, frankly, of the gospel is you can still be father.
Yeah, makes sense, makes total sense. And if I can add one more suggestion and thought in here,
one of the things that I've been really involved with lately is teaching young men in our church
and in our neighborhood. And there's also some sort of joy and satisfaction of helping a lot
of these boys who frankly won't get it outside of their opportunity to engage with me. There is an
opportunity for me to participate in that to a degree as well. And I would just tell every man
who's listening, like get involved in the community because there are other young boys and young men
who need what you may not have had growing up. Yeah, and that's so good. That's so good because
the initiation will take place as you're offering it. And also just ask yourself, like, where would
you love to grow? Where would you love to be strengthened? You know, if you're the kind of guy
that wasn't raised around sports, maybe you'd like to go take a class and learn how to, you know,
I don't know, shoot a ball, throw a curve ball, like go deliberately into those places that you
want to get stronger. You know, if you never have wood shop in school as a kid, you know, there's a
lot of classes on that offered in City College now in the evening. So you can put yourself into
those training experiences that will strengthen your inner life. And this is so valuable. I've got
my first hunt. I've never hunted in my life. I've got my first hunt coming up next week. Later in
the year, I'm going to Tim Kennedy's sheepdog response training, where I get to shoot guns and
roll around on the mat with him and other guys like, I'm really excited about this kind of stuff
because yes, it pushes me outside of my comfort zone. But it's exactly what I think is needed to
develop more masculinity in my life. Yeah, I love that. I love that intentionality. Chase it. Go find
it. Gentlemen, just a quick timeout. The battle that John has referenced in this podcast is one
that I set out on for myself years ago. What I found was there was no battle plan, no guidance,
no direction, and no one to take this journey of becoming a better man with me. So I actually
just set out to create it. And that's exactly what I did when I created the iron council. This is our
exclusive brotherhood dedicated to giving you the tools and the resources and the battle plan required
to thrive in your life. And when you join us, you'll be banding together with brothers and arms who
are in the same battle as you, the battle for your career, the battle for your marriage and family
and the battle for your life. So if you're ready to join us, gain the knowledge and the skills and
the tools to arm yourself with the resources that you're going to need to engage in this fight,
you can join us inside of the iron council at order of man.com slash iron council.
Again, that's order of man.com slash iron council. Now let's get back to the conversation with John.
One of the other things that you have mentioned in the book, and I can't remember exactly where
it is in the book, but you talk about essentially doing the opposite, and that's probably not the
right word, but doing the opposite of what you're accustomed to. So if you're accustomed to
being the guy that sits in the corner and doesn't really share his any of his insights or wording,
then be the guy who actually now goes out and shares and is more vocal about his ideas.
I think sometimes just doing something different than you've ever done or have done.
Yeah, this is huge because of the lack of validation and because of the wounding,
because of the scripts that we were handed, you know, in school, in sports, whatever,
most men are now faking it. Most of what you meet when you meet a man is a brilliant disguise.
In the book, I call it the poser. Every guy has perfected the poser. And so for one guy,
it's he's really smart. And for another guy, he's really funny. And for another guy,
he's just always silent. You know, and another guy, he's he's awesome at sports, and that's what
he leads with. But the point is you're hiding behind the poser. And when I talk about do the
opposite, you have these inclinations, like you've always got to be in control. You got to let that
go if you want to find a genuine strength. Like if you want to grow in genuine courage and strength,
you've got to stop doing the things you do to hide. So stop, stop cracking jokes all the time.
You know, you don't have to be the funny guy all the time. Yeah. Or for another guy, like you
were saying, if you're just silent, and you never speak up, it's time to speak up. You're hiding
behind that. And so the idea of doing the opposite of what you normally do is the idea of coming out
of hiding. One of the quotes that you had mentioned in the book, I actually wrote this down in my notes
as I was preparing for our conversation. It says, the world of posers is shaken by a real man,
and they'll do whatever they can to get you back in line. Now, I think this is kind of talking about
the inverse relationship, right? Somebody else being a poser in our
tendency to fall in line with what somebody else believes about us or the way that we should act.
Oh, totally. I had lunch with a guy last week who's a really good guy. And we were chatting about
hunting because he happens to be like really into hunting. But after lunch, I found myself
totally exhausted. Like I was just fried. And I had to ask myself, why? Why? And the reason is this,
is because I had to hide most of who I am to hang out with this guy. Like in other words,
he's got a way of doing life. He's got a chit chat. He's got a banter. He's got,
and the message is you stay within this boundary. Don't talk about heavy stuff.
Definitely don't start talking about God and don't go outside this boundary. And I was so exhausted
afterwards of trying to live within his little circle. And it's guys like the world is full of
stuff. You work with posers. You go to church with posers. Your family reunions are full of
posers. And the pull to be a poser yourself is pretty strong and something you have to intentionally
resist. And you talk about also, and I'm just paraphrasing here, but stepping into your strength
and knowing that people are going to be intimidated by you being fully who you are.
Yeah, exactly. Yeah. So what? One of the most disruptive things one of my mentors said to me
years and years ago, because I was hiding, I was posing, I was, oh man, just doing all that stuff.
Every guy does. And here's what he said to me. He says, let people feel the weight of who you are
and let them deal with it. And to this day, like that reverberates in my soul. Like just,
you have a strength to offer the world. You are a man. Offer it. And don't be so worried about
how they handle it. They may not be able to handle it. That's okay. Be who you are.
I like that. Because I've always thought, you know, people are going to respond. But the way that
they respond to what you're doing is just a representation of the way they feel and who they are. It doesn't
really say anything about who you are. Totally. Totally. And the world is threatened by a real
man. I mean, let's just be honest. You're at a staff meeting at work and everybody's just
kissing up to the boss and you raise your hand and say, you know, I don't think that's a good idea.
I don't think this company ought to go in that direction. People are going to be threatened by
that. People are threatened by a genuine strength. But the thing is, is that the world needs a
genuine strength. There is a quality to masculinity that I think is powerfully pictured in
the firemen and the pararesky, the guys who went up the stairs of the World Trade Center
when everybody else was running down on 9-11. Like everybody was piling down those stairwells.
Obviously try and get out of there. But there was a group of guys who went up. And that choice,
that choice of courage and self-sacrifice is the essence of masculinity.
It's such a good point. You know what's really funny is, it seems to me that society and media
and the government and everybody else will ridicule and mock masculinity until something goes wrong.
And you look around and you see when things go wrong, I think of pictures and stories that I heard
about these hurricanes in Texas and Florida and Puerto Rico. And you see these authentic men
doing what it is men do. And nobody complains when things are going wrong. It's only when things
are perfect. It's kind of interesting. I love that. There was a fabulous story
they called it the Cajun Navy. And during the flooding down in Texas,
dudes, regular dudes showed up with their boats. And they were guys that knew how to handle the
water. They knew how to tie a knot. They knew how to pull somebody out. They knew how to navigate
through, because they've been doing it all their life. These are fishermen. These are guys who are
familiar with boats. And it was thousands of just guys in their small personal craft that performed
most of the rescues. And that's what you're saying. The world doesn't want masculinity until it
needs it. And then it's like, please show up. Please rescue us.
Yeah, is this now is this the notion of authentic masculinity? Or is it deeper than this or something
else? Help me understand that. Yeah, it is. Because having a genuine strength to offer the world
is what it means to be a man. And for those guys, it was expressing it in courage and the handling
of a boat. But it can be expressed in so many different ways. What we're talking about is we're
talking about the masculine journey. We're talking about coming out from the false self,
putting down the poser, seeking the initiation that you need as a man to grow as a man and
offering what you have to the world. So one of my favorite quotes, I quote this all the time,
the guys are going to hear this and they're going to roll their eyes because they say it all the time.
And that's your quote. And it's deep in his heart. Every man longs for a battle to fight
an adventure to live in a beauty to rescue. I'd like to break down each one of these when you're
talking about a battle to fight. What types of battles are we talking about here that men can
engage in? Oh my gosh, they're coming at you every day. They are coming at you every day.
Every guy wakes up to this. You got battles in your home battles for relationship. If you want
friendship, you have to fight for it. If you want a marriage, you have to fight for it. If you have
kids, Ryan, you know, you have to fight for their hearts. And fight for it is the only best description
because there's the busyness. There's the self absorption. There's the oh man, I don't want to
have this conversation tonight. I just want to watch the game. There's the doubt. Do I have what it
takes to be a good father? Do I have what it takes to handle my wife's emotions? Do I have what it
takes to talk to my 16 year old daughter about her boyfriend? The reason we avoid these places is
usually fear, fear and self preservation. And so they are battles because you have to you have to
operate in courage to move into those places. There's battles at work. There's battles in your
community. If your kids are in school, I guarantee you there's a fight for their education.
And then how about your dreams? How about your own dreams of what you want your life to be like,
how about some of those things you wanted to chase or to see happen? You're going to have to
fight for your dreams. And every one of these is a place to develop the warrior in you.
I really like that you'd use that term battle because I think it's very easy for us to get into
the monotonous grind of life. And we've got this task and this chore and we've got to take the
trash out and we've got to do X and Y and Z. And I know for me personally, when I framed it as a
battle, for example, I wake up in the morning and don't want to roll out of bed. And I look at
